In 1891, the [[Salvation Army]] opened up its own match factory in Bow, London, using harmless red phosphorus and paying better wages.<ref name=spartacus /> Part of the reason behind this match factory was the desire to improve the conditions of home workers, including children, who dipped yellow phosphorus-based matches at home.<ref name=emsley-115-126>Emsley, 115-126.</ref> Several children died from eating these matches. Interestingly, the Salvation Army match factory had lower rates of Phossy jaw than did the Bryant and May in the same locality; and this was due to improved working conditions.{{fact}}
The Bryant and May factory received bad publicity from these events, and in 1901 they announced that their factory no longer used yellow phosphorous.<ref name=spartacus /> Ironically, the owners ([[Francis May (industrialist)|Francis May]] and [[William Bryant (industrialist)|William Bryant]]), who were both [[Religious Society of Friends|Quakers]], opened their own match factory specifically to make safety matches.{{fact}} They started using red phosphorus in 1855, but could not compete against the much cheaper yellow phosphorus-based matches.

The Salvation Army had the same problem; their own matches were initially three-times the price of yellow phosphorus-based matches. They had some partial success, because many of their supporters refused to buy yellow phosphorus-based matches; they automated much of the match making processes, but not box filling; and, the use of Child Labour in dangerous trades was prohibited. The factory still struggled to compete on price; and after 1898 the ''War Cry'' ceased to advertise their matches.{{Emsley, P115 -126 fact}} Their last make or break advertisment was run on [[24 Febrary]] [[1900]].{{Emsley, P115 - 126 fact}} The Salvation Army match factory finally closed and it was taken over by Bryant and May on [[26 November]] [[1901]]. {{Emsley, P125 fact}}

The use of yellow-phosphorus matches was not made illegal in the United Kingdom until an Act was passed in 1908, prohibiting the use of yellow phosphorus in matches after 31 December 1910. This was the United Kingdom's implementation of the 1906 [[Berne]] Convention on the prohibition of white phosphorus in matches.{{Emsley, P125 fact}}
